extension.description: libretro port of bNES, a NES emulator.[CR][CR]Authors: byuu, Ryphecha.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/bnes-libretro
extension.broken: Poor performance and reported crashes. Use FCEU-Next.

extension.description: Libretro implementation of the core emulation in bSNES, a Super Nintendo (SNES) emulator.[CR][CR]libsnes/bsnes author: byuu[CR][CR]Porters: Ver Greeneyes, Themaister[CR][CR]Source: http://gitorious.org/bsnes/bsnes

Libretro implementation of the core emulation in bSNES, a Super Nintendo (SNES) emulator.[CR][CR]libsnes/bsnes author: byuu[CR][CR]Porters: Ver Greeneyes, Themaister[CR][CR]Source: http://gitorious.org/bsnes/bsnes

Libretro implementation of the core emulation in bSNES, a Super Nintendo (SNES) emulator.[CR][CR]libsnes/bsnes author: byuu[CR][CR]Porters: Ver Greeneyes, Themaister[CR][CR]Source: http://gitorious.org/bsnes/bsnes

DeSmuME is software that allows you to emulate a Nintendo DS system. And best of all, this software is completely free and open-source.[CR][CR]Special thanks to: yopyop (original author of DeSmuME), for releasing the source code of this great emulator; Martin Korth (author of GBATEK), for his well-written Gameboy Advance and Nintendo DS documentation.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/desmume-libretro

Final Burn Alpha is an emulator of arcade games. Currently, FB Alpha supports games on Capcom CPS-1 and CPS-2 hardware, SNK Neo-Geo hardware, Toaplan hardware, Cave hardware, and various games on miscellaneous hardware. Recent releases have started to add back in Sega System 16 emulation. FB Alpha is an open-source project and it is programmed by a group of people known as the FBA Team. Over the years this has comprised of Barry Harris, Jan_Klaassen, KEV, LoopMaster, Mike Haggar, Hyper Yagami and Ayeye. FB Alpha is based on the original FinalBurn by Dave.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/fba-libretro
extension.disclaimer: The authors of FB Alpha don't guarantee its fitness for any purpose, implied or otherwise, and do not accept responsibility for any damages whatsoever that might occur when using FB Alpha. All games emulated by FB Alpha, including any images and sounds therein, are copyrighted by their respective copyright holders.

extension.description: Port of FCEUmm / FCEUX to Libretro. FCEUX is a Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), Famicom, and Famicom Disk System (FDS) emulator. FCEUX is an evolution of the original FCE Ultra emulator. Over time FCE Ultra had separated into many distinct branches. The concept behind FCEUX is to merge elements from FCEU Ultra, FCEU rerecording, FCEUXD, FCEUXDSP, FCEUXDSP CE, and FCEU-mm into a single branch of FCEU.[CR][CR]Authors: byuu, Ryphecha.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/fceu-next

Gambatte is an accuracy-focused, open-source, cross-platform Game Boy Color emulator written in C++. It is based on hundreds of corner case hardware tests, as well as previous documentation and reverse engineering efforts.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/gambatte-libretro
extension.disclaimer: Game Boy and Game Boy Color are registered trademarks of Nintendo of America, Inc. Gambatte is not affiliated with or endorsed by any of the companies mentioned.

extension.description: An enhanced port of Genesis Plus to the libretro API. Support for SG-1000, Mark-III, Master System, Game Gear, Mega Drive & Mega CD hardware.[CR][CR]Enhancements backported by twinaphex from the GX version (Gamecube/Wii port), maintained by Eke-Eke.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/Genesis-Plus-GX

This is a proof of concept build based on MAME 0.78.[CR][CR]MAME stands for [B]M[/B]ultiple [B]A[/B]rcade [B]M[/B]achine [B]E[/B]mulator. When used in conjunction with images of the original arcade game's ROM and disk data, MAME attempts to reproduce that game as faithfully as possible on a more modern general-purpose computer. MAME can currently emulate several thousand different classic arcade video games from the late 1970s through the modern era.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/mame078-libretro

Mednafen is a portable multi-system emulator. This is port of the Mednafen PCE core to the libretro API. The "pce_fast" emulation module is an experimental alternative to the pce emulation module. It is a fork of 0.8.x modified for speed at the expense of (usually) unneeded accuracy.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/mednafen-libretro

Mednafen is a portable multi-system emulator. This is port of the Mednafen PSX core to the libretro API.[CR][CR]PlayStation 1 emulation is currently in a buggy alpha state and not all hardware and features are emulated. A dual-core Phenom II or Athlon II at 3GHz or higher, or rough equivalent, is recommended for running Mednafen's PlayStation 1 emulation. PSF1 playback is supported.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/mednafen-libretro

Mednafen is a portable multi-system emulator. This is port of the Mednafen WonderSwan core to the libretro API.[CR][CR]Mednafen's WonderSwan (Color) emulation is based off of Cygne. WSR (WonderSwan sound rip format) playback is supported.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/mednafen-libretro

Meteor is a Nintendo Gameboy Advance emulator.[CR][CR]Authors: Philippe Daouadi <p.daouadi@free.fr>, Hans-Kristian Arntzen (libretro port and fixes) <maister@archlinux.us>[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/meteor-libretro

Nestopia is a portable open source NES/Famicom emulator. It is designed to be as accurate as possible and supports a large number of peripherals. The hardware is emulated at cycle-by-cycle granularity, ensuring full support for software that does mid-scanline and other timing trickery.[CR][CR]Nestopia Undead is a fork of the original source code, plus R. Belmont's Linux port overlay, all included in one convenient source tree with enhancements.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/nestopia

NXEngine is a complete open-source clone/rewrite of the masterpiece jump-and-run platformer Doukutsu Monogatari (also known as Cave Story).[CR][CR]Original author: Caitlin Shaw (rogueeve)[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/nxengine-libretro

PrBoom is a version of the classic 3D shoot'em'up game Doom, originally written by id Software.[CR][CR]PrBoom is a game engine - it provides a program to play Doom levels, but it doesn't include any levels itself. To play PrBoom, you need one of the main Doom date files (called the IWAD) from id Software - doom.wad, doom2.wad, tnt.wad or plutonia.wad - or the shareware doom1.wad.[CR][CR]If you don't own any of the Doom games, get the shareware doom1.wad from doom19s.zip on Doomworld's shareware download page. http://www.doomworld.com/files/shareware.shtml[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/libretro-prboom
The QuickNES core library, originally by Shay Green, heavily modified. QuickNES is a newer emulator that seems to have good compatibility.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/QuickNES_Core
Snes9x-Next is based on Snes9x, but has been heavily modified/speed-hacked to achieve better speed.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/snes9x-next

Snes9x is a portable, freeware Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES) emulator. It basically allows you to play most games designed for the SNES and Super Famicom Nintendo game systems on your PC or Workstation; which includes some real gems that were only ever released in Japan.[CR][CR]Snes9x is the result of well over three years worth of part-time hacking, coding, recoding, debugging, divorce, etc. (just kidding about the divorce bit). Snes9x is coded in C++, with three assembler CPU emulation cores on the i386 Linux and Windows ports.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/snes9xgit/snes9x
extension.disclaimer: The Snes9X team is not connected or affiliated with any mentioned company in any way. The opinions of the Snes9X team do not reflect the views of the various companies mentioned here. Companies and all products pertaining to that company are trademarks of that company. Please contact that company for trademark and copyright information.

extension.description: Stella is a multi-platform Atari 2600 VCS emulator. The Atari 2600 Video Computer System (VCS), introduced in 1977, was the most popular home video game system of the early 1980's. Now you can enjoy all of your favorite Atari 2600 games on your PC thanks to Stella![CR][CR]Stella was originally developed for Linux by Bradford W. Mott, and is currently maintained by Stephen Anthony.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/stella-libretro
VBA-Next is a fork from the now inactive VisualBoy Advance project, with goals to improve the capatibility and features of the emulator.[CR][CR]Source: https://github.com/libretro/vba-next
